questions.question_text: An engineer must design a routing solution for a company that is single-homed to an ISP. The company’s goal is to run BGP between the CE and the PE devices. To support running BGP, the company obtained a public AS number and IP subnet from ARIN. Which solution must the engineer select?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. The customer announces the public IP subnet to the ISP, and the ISP announces the default route to the customer.

In this scenario, to support running BGP between the CE and PE devices, the engineer must select the solution in which the customer announces the public IP subnet to the ISP, and the ISP announces the default route to the customer. This approach enables the customer to control the routing of their IP subnet while also receiving the default route from the ISP for reaching destinations outside of their network.

Refer to the exhibit. An engineer is planning an IPv4 to IPv6 migration solution for a customer. The routers in the network can support IPv4 and IPv6, except for the DWDM routers. The DWDM routers provide a Layer 2 link in which the routers peer directly with each other across a DWDM circuit. The circuit also provides connectivity between the mail servers. Which IPv6 migration technique must the engineer deploy?

discussion.content: I think isatap is best answer for this question. We don't need to 6to4 translation because DWDM routers working on the layer 2. So we can choose the A

Selected Answer: A
Since the DWDM routers don't support IPv6 and provide a Layer 2 link, the appropriate IPv6 migration technique to deploy in this scenario is:

A. ISATAP (Intra-Site Automatic Tunnel Addressing Protocol)

ISATAP is used to provide IPv6 connectivity across an IPv4-only infrastructure, allowing IPv6 packets to be encapsulated within IPv4 packets. It's typically used within a site or organization to facilitate IPv6 communication. Since the DWDM routers provide a Layer 2 link and don't support IPv6 directly, ISATAP can be used to enable IPv6 connectivity between the routers across the DWDM circuit, even though the DWDM routers themselves are not IPv6-capable.
